Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Micro-Fluidic LiDAR for Autonomous Vehicles
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is to hasten the deployment of autonomous transportation systems, which stand to reduce driving accidents and fatalities, enable new paradigms in urban design, reduce vehicle traffic, increase automobile efficiency, and improve air quality, benefiting the immediate health of drivers and non-drivers alike. Advanced Driver Assistance Systems (ADAS) are simpler implantations of semi-autonomous controls systems, but are already saving lives by providing intelligent cruise control, lane departure warnings, steering assistance, and preemptive emergency braking. As ADAS improves through advanced sensor hardware developed in this work and becomes more widely deployed, more accident will be avoided and lives saved. Autonomous vehicles are expected to accelerate current trends from private ownership of multiple vehicles to transportation services, such as Uber and Lyft, and autonomous vehicle services, a trend evident in New York city and San Francisco, where parking lot capacity is dropping. As carpool lanes have promoted wiser commuting and reduced congestion, future autonomous lanes can enable platooning, where vehicles travel at reduced distances between each other at high speed, reducing drag, increasing fuel economy, and better utilizing public infrastructure.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will result in a vision system that delivers three dimensional data of objects in view, allowing for the widespread adoption of delivery robots, drones, advanced driver safety systems in vehicles, and autonomous vehicles. To deliver performance and reliability at a cost that enabled wide adoption, the company will address the challenges facing incumbent technologies with two key technological innovations: A high speed, wide angle laser beam steering technology based on magneto-hydro-dynamics, and the use of neutrally buoyant optomechanics. These two innovations allow for light beams to be swept across a wide field of view, delivering 3D point cloud data at high frame rate with operational immunity to vibrations from road hazards such as pot holes and speed bumps. The end objective of the research is to demonstrate a fully functionally imaging system operating with components developed in this work. It is anticipated that the developed components will implement precise spatial control of laser sources by a low cost electromagnetic drive motor, demonstrating performance metrics consistent with deployment on production vehicles.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mirada’s Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project developed an automotive grade laser scanning system that enables next generation LiDAR, a three dimensional vision technology crucial for the widespread adoption of autonomous delivery robots, drones, advanced driver safety systems in vehicles, and autonomous vehicles.  To deliver performance and reliability at a cost that enables wide adoption, we address the challenges facing incumbent technologies with a technological breakthrough: neutrally buoyant optomechanics.  This innovation allows for a pulsed light beam to be swept across a wide field of view, delivering 3D point cloud data at high frame rate, and doing it while immune to vibrations from pot holes, speed bumps, etc.  This work will result in, through close partnerships with our customers in the autonomous vehicle value chain, a new class of vision systems that will bring a new level of efficiency and safety in transportation.

Our technology will overcome the reliability and cost constraints currently plaguing the LiDAR based vision system market.  LiDAR vision systems for transportation are currently available from a very limited number of providers, cost up to $70,000 each, and use moving parts that do not meet automotive reliability standards.  By removing these constraints and delivering a micro-fluidic enabled, human eye inspired LiDAR vision system, we help enable a wide range of societal benefits due to widespread autonomous transportation systems.  Advanced Driver Assistance Systems (ADAS) already are saving many lives by providing intelligent cruise control, lane departure warnings, preemptive braking in emergencies, and steering assistance.  As ADAS continues to improve through advanced sensor hardware, such as Mirada is developing, and becomes more widely deployed, many more accidents will be avoided and many lives saved.  As semi and full autonomous driving technology transitions from limited tests on city streets to ubiquity, there are many aspects of our lives that promise to be transformed.  Autonomous vehicles are predicted to accelerate current trends from private ownership of multiple vehicles to reliance on car sharing, ride services such as Uber and Lyft, and autonomous vehicle services.  This trend is already evident in cities such as New York City and San Francisco where usage of and rates for private parking lots have begun to fall.  These changes, coupled with government regulation that allows for the melding of these modes of transport with public transit systems can reduce total road vehicle traffic, vehicle pollution, and by extension improve the health of all citizens.  As carpool lanes have promoted wiser commuting and reduced congestion, future autonomous only lanes can allow platooning, where these vehicles are in constant communication with each other, allowing them to travel extremely close at high speed, reduce drag, increase fuel economy, and better utilize public infrastructure.
